qas.question: What usually played a larger role than laws regarding a person's race?
Where did people not ask about racial background?
What were the hallmarks of free citizens?

answers.text: they served in the militia and voted

qas.question: What had different laws regarding color after the one-drop rule?
What played the smallest role in how a person was perceived?
In what areas were there the most questions about origins?
What was not a factor in how communities looked at people?
What was never based on how people were accepted by their neighbors?

context: Prior to the one-drop rule, <b4_0>different states<b4_0/> had different laws regarding color. More importantly, <a0_0><b5_0>social acceptance<b5_0/><a0_0/> often played a bigger role in how a person was perceived and how identity was construed than any law. In <a1_0><b6_0>frontier<b6_0/> areas<a1_0/>, there were fewer questions about origins. The community looked at <b7_0>how people performed<b7_0/>, whether <a2_0>they served in the militia and voted<a2_0/>, which were the responsibilities and signs of free citizens. When questions about racial identity arose because of inheritance issues, for instance, <b8_0>litigation outcomes<b8_0/> often were based on how people were accepted by <a3_0>neighbors<a3_0/>.
